metadata.title: Mixed matrix membrane of nano-zeolite NaX/poly (ether-block-amide) for gas separation applications

sections.text:
In this work, mixed matrix membranes (MMMs) were prepared by incorporating nano-zeolite NaX into poly (ether-block-amide) (Pebax-1657) as an active layer on the polyethersulfone (PES) membrane as a support layer. The influence of filler content, zeolite particle size and operating conditions on the gas separation performance of the prepared membranes were studied. In order to achieve this aim, the zeolite NaX nanoparticles, which were fabricated by the hydrothermal technique using microwave heating, were uniformly distributed in the polymer solution by a two-step procedure for preparation of the membrane casting solution and the mixed matrix membrane was fabricated via the phase inversion technique by solvent evaporation. The prepared membranes were characterized by the ATR-FTIR, AFM, SEM, DSC and contact angle analyses. The gas permeation results revealed that incorporation of nano-zeolite NaX into the Pebax-1657 membrane decreased the gas permeability for all tested gases, while the ideal selectivity for CO2/N2 and O2/N2 significantly enhanced. Also, the mixed matrix membranes containing nano-sized zeolite had superior gas separation performance in comparison with the micro-sized zeolite loaded membrane. It was found that the CO2/N2 selectivity enhanced from
98.0 to 121.5 with increasing the feed pressure, while the O2/N2 selectivity decreased from 7.8 to 4.2. For CO2/N2 separation, the membrane containing 2%wt. nano-zeolite at the operating pressure of 7 bar and temperature of 25°C overcomes the Robeson’s upper bound and showed fairly good gas separation performance, compared with the similar Pebax mixed matrix membranes in the literature.
Keywords: Mixed matrix membrane; Gas separation; Pebax-1657; Nano-zeolite NaX; Carbon dioxide

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
In recent years, mixed matrix membranes (MMMs) have been extensively used in the membrane gas separation process due to good mechanical, chemical and thermal stability as well as high permeability and selectivity in comparison to pure polymeric membranes. The MMMs, which are prepared by incorporating inorganic materials as the dispersed phase into the polymeric matrix as the continuous phase, have the advantages of both inorganic and polymeric materials [1, 2]. Despite these advantages, the separation performance and properties of the MMMs are considerably affected by non-uniform distribution of inorganic filler in the polymeric matrix and defects formation at the polymer/filler interface. Choosing material for the dispersed and continuous phases is an important aspect in improvement of the separation performance of the MMMs [3]. The most important issue for the polymer material in the MMMs is to make sure there is good adhesion between two phases. In this regard, a new type of polymer material, block copolymers including both rigid and flexible polymer chains have been used to prepare the MMMs. Using the special soft-rigid structure of block copolymer leads to an increase in the
adhesion strength between the polymer and inorganic particle besides the good mechanical resistance [4-6]. Poly (ether block amide) (PEBA) that is known under the trade name of PEBAX, is a block copolymer obtained by condensation polymerization of a carboxylic acid polyamide with a polyether. Different grades of PEBA have been manufactured by changing the ether and amide composition for gas separation applications [7, 8]. Among them, Pebax-1657, which consists of 40% polyamide6 (PA6) as hard segment and 60% polyethylene oxide (PEO) as soft segment, has provided particular high selectivity for polar/nonpolar gas separation such as CO2/N2due to the high affinity between polar gas and the PEO segment [9-13]. The permeating molecules pass through the flexible polyether blocks and the hard polyamide blocks provide the mechanical stability of the membrane. Due to the outstanding properties, the Pebax-1657 has been extensively used to prepare the mixed matrix membranes for the gas separation application. Various porous inorganic materials such as zeolite [14-16], carbon nanotubes (CNTs) [10, 13], ordered mesoporous silica [17] and zeolitic imidazole frameworks (ZIFs) [11] as well as different nonporous inorganic materials like silica and metal oxides [12, 13, 18, 19] have been employed as filler into the Pebax-1657 matrix to prepare membrane for the gas separation. For instance, Murali et al. [10] investigated the influence of incorporating MWCNT into the Pebax1657 and they found the selectivity of CO2/N2 and CO2/H2 enhanced after CNT loading. Li et al. [11] prepared the Pebax-1657/ZIF-7 MMMs for the gas separation application and observed that the separation performance of CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 improved by the addition of ZIF-7. Wu et al. [17] used polyethyleneimine functionalized ordered mesoporous silica (PEI-MCM-41) to improve the separation performance of the Pebax-1657 membrane.
Furthermore, zeolites are the most prevalent inorganic materials utilized for fabricating MMMs [5, 6]. Incorporation of zeolite particles into the rubbery polymer and copolymer has displayed significant development in the separation performance. Zhao et al. [14] reported that the permeability of CO2, N2, H2 and CH4 of the Pebax-1657/SAPO-34 MMMs enhanced significantly at high SAPO-34 content, while the selectivity of CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 did not increase considerably. Murali et al. [15]studied the influence of loading zeolite 4A into the Pebax-1657 membrane on the gas separation properties by measuring the permeability of CO2, N2, O2 and CH4. They reported that the permeability of all tested gases and the ideal selectivity of O2/N2, CO2/N2 and CO2/CH4 enhanced with increasing zeolite loading. Bryan et al. [16] investigated the gas permeation properties of the Pebax-1657/micro-sized zeolite 13X MMMs for the CO2/N2 separation. They observed an increase in the CO2 permeability with increasing zeolite content and the highest CO2/N2 selectivity at the maximum zeolite loading. Moreover, the particle size of the filler is one of the important elements, which affects the gas separation properties of MMMs. Generally, the nano-sized filler has better performance in both of the gas permeability and the gas pair selectivity because of their unique phase morphology and high surface area [20, 21]. A search through the current literature revealed that there is no research on the use of nano-zeolite NaX as filler in the mixed matrix membranes of Pebax. The inorganic fillers in the micro-form were utilized in most of the previous studies. In this study, two-layer mixed matrix membranes were fabricated by incorporating zeolite NaX particle into the Pebax-1657 as the selective top layer on the polyethersulfone (PES) ultrafiltration membrane as the support layer. The zeolite NaX nanoparticles were synthesized by the hydrothermal method using microwave heating and their structure, Si/Al ratio and particle size were characterized by XRD, XRF, DLS and FESEM analyses. The effects of zeolite loading, zeolite
particle size, feed pressure and operating temperature on the gas separation performance of the MMMs were investigated by measuring the pure gas permeability of CO2, N2 and O2. The prepared membranes were also analyzed by SEM, AFM, DSC, ATR-FTIR and contact angle analysis to study the effect of filler content on the morphological, thermal and chemical properties and polarity of the membranes. The main innovative aspect of this study is the use of nanofillers to prepare mixed matrix membranes for the gas separation applications. Also, for comparison, the commercial micro-sized zeolite NaX has been employed as filler. Another important contribution is the investigation of effect of operating temperature and pressure on the gas separation performance of the prepared mixed matrix membranes.

sections.heading: 2.1. Materials
sections.text: The commercial Pebax® MH 1657 (60 %wt. PEO and 40 %wt. PA6) and PES with molecular weight of 58000 g/mol (Ultrason E6020P) supplied from Arkema Inc. (Paris, France) and BASF (Ludwigshafen, Germany),respectively, were used as the membrane material. N,N-Dimethylformamide (DMF) and formic acid purchased from Merck Co. Ltd. (Darmstadt, Germany) were used as organic solvents. Sodium aluminate (NaAlO2) (Sigma Aldrich, USA), fumed silica (7 nm, Sigma Aldrich, USA) and NaOH (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) were also utilized for the synthesis of zeolite nanoparticles. The commercial micro-sized zeolite NaX was supplied by Zeochem Co. Ltd. (ZEOCHEM ® Molecular Sieves 13X, Zeochem Co. Ltd., Switzerland). Moreover, CO2, O2and N2 gases with purity of 99.99% were used as feed gas.

sections.heading: 2.2. Nano-zeolite NaX synthesis
sections.text: The zeolite NaX nanoparticles were prepared by the hydrothermal method using microwave heating based on the procedure presented by Ansari et al. [22]. Typically, an aluminosilicate gel was prepared by mixing raw materials in the molar ratio of 5.5 Na2O:1.0 Al2O3:4.0 SiO2:190 H2O. For this purpose, 2.67 g of NaOH was solved in 25 g of de-ionized water and stirred well. Before the next step, the obtained solution was cooled to room temperature, and then 1.21 g of NaAlO2 was added to the solution and stirred continuously until all the powder is completely dissolved in the NaOH solution. Afterwards, 1.715 g of silica powder was slowly added to the solution until a homogeneous aluminosilicate reaction gel was obtained. The prepared gel was regularly stirred at room temperature for 24 h, and then transferred into a commercial microwave oven (CE1110C, Samsung, Korea) to perform the hydrothermal crystallization by microwave heating at 90°C for 3 h. The microwave oven was operated at a wavelength of 2.45 GHz with 900 W output power. The products were regained with centrifugation, washed with de-ionized water until the pH value reached below 8, and then for further characterization, dried at room temperature for 24 h.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Porous PES substrate preparation
sections.text:
The porous PES membrane used as the substrate for the preparation of mixed matrix membranes were prepared by the non-solvent induced phase separation(NIPS) method according to the procedure presented by Sadeghi et al. [23]. For this purpose, the dried PES granules (16 %wt.) were typically dissolved into the DMF solvent and then underwent vigorous stirring until a clear homogeneous solution was obtained. The bubble-free homogeneous PES solution was then
casted on a glass plate with a casting knife and instantly immersed into a de-ionized water bath as non-solvent at room temperature. In the non-solvent bath, the phase inversion process was done and the formed PES membranes were separated from the glass plate. The obtained membranes were stored in another de-ionized water bath for 24 h for complete removal of the residual solvent from the PES membranes. Finally, the PES membrane was dried at room temperature for 24 h. The thickness of the prepared PES support layer measured by a micrometer was 60±5 µm.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Mixed matrix membranes preparation
sections.text:
The Pebax-1657/zeolite NaX mixed matrix membranes were prepared by the solvent evaporation induced phase separation (EIPS) method. Fig. 1 shows the step preparing procedure of the MMM dope solution. At first, the Pebax granules were dissolved in formic acid and then the prepared solution was vehemently stirred at room temperature over night to obtain a clear homogenous polymer solution. A suspension of zeolite NaX was prepared by adding a specific amount of zeolite particles to the formic acid and sonicating for 30 min. Then, a quarter of the Pebax solution was added to the zeolite suspension, stirred for 30 min and sonicated for 15 min. This procedure was continued until all of the polymer solution was added to the zeolite suspension and a homogenous casting solution was obtained. Afterwards, the polymer solution was deaerated by a vacuum process for 2h and sonicated for 30 min before casting. The bubble-free Pebax/zeolite solution was cast on the porous PES support membrane which was placed on a glass plate with a casting knife. The obtained film was allowed to dry in an oven at 35 °C for 24h. The thickness of the prepared MMMs measured by a micrometer was 75±5 µm. The composition of casting solution for the preparation of various membranes is given in Table 1.
Fig. 1: Scheme of the MMM dope solution preparing procedure.

sections.heading: 2.4.1. XRD and XRF analyses
sections.text:
The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of the prepared zeolite powder was analyzed on a Philips instrument (X’pert diffractometer) with a CuK X-ray source and a scanning speed of 0.03° (2θ) min -1 to certify the zeolite NaX structure. Scherrer’s equation was used to calculate the average
crystal size of the zeolite NaX. The zeolite crystallinity was also determined from the area of the peaks at 2θ of 6°, 16° and 27° [22]. The X-ray fluorescence (XRF) analysis using a Philips spectrometer (PW 1404 spectrometer, Philips X'pert, Eindhovan, Netherlands) was also used to determine the elemental compositions and Si/Al ratio of the synthesized zeolite NaX nanoparticles.

sections.heading: 2.4.2. DLS analysis
sections.text: The dynamic light scattering (DLS) using a Malvern Zetasizer Nano (Malvern Instruments, Worcestershire) (Wavelength: 632.8 nm, Scattering angle: 173°) was applied in order to measure particle size distribution of nano-zeolite NaX. The zeolite crystals were re-dispersed in water by 1 h sonication at 20°C for the DLS analysis.

sections.heading: 2.4.3. FESEM and SEM analyses
sections.text: The morphological characterization and particle size of the zeolite NaX were determined by the field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) (VEGA 3SB, TESCAN, Czech Republic). The surface and cross-sectional morphologies of the prepared MMMs were studied by SEM images from the top surface and cross-section of the membranes with a SEM device (Seron Technology, AIS2100, South Korea) at a high voltage of 20 kV.

sections.heading: 2.4.4. ATR-FTIR analysis
sections.text:
The attenuated total reflection-fourier transforms infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy was also employed to characterize the presence of functional groups on the pure Pebax-1657 membrane and Pebax-1657/zeolite MMMs. The FTIR spectra were obtained using a Nicolet Nexus 670
spectrometer (Nicolet Instrument Co., Madison, WI, USA) with a resolution of 4 cm -1 over a wave number range of 4000-600 cm −1 . An average of 15 scans collected from the surface 2cm × 4cm sample of the membranes was reported.

sections.heading: 2.4.5. AFM analysis
sections.text: The surface roughness of different membranes was measured using atomic force microscopy (AFM). The AFM analysis was accomplished using a microscope (Nano Educator, NTMDT Co., Zelenograd, Russia) that was calibrated by the standard samples (TGG1 and TGX1, NT-MDT Co., Zelenograd, Russia) with a spatial resolution of ~2nm in z direction. Four different locations of each sample were analyzed and the average values of roughness were reported. The roughness was expressed in terms of RMS (root mean square) and RA (average roughness) values.

sections.heading: 2.4.6. DSC analysis
sections.text: In order to examine the glass transient temperature (Tg) of the pure Pebax-1657 membrane and Pebax-1657/zeolite MMMs, differential scanning calorimeter (DSC) analysis was performed by the DSC1 instrument (Mettler-Toledo Inc., Switzerland). The samples were heated from -100 to 220 °C under pure argon atmosphere with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The glass transition temperature was measured during first scan.

sections.heading: 2.4.6. Contact angle analysis
sections.text:
The hydrophilicity/hydrophobicity of the prepared membranes was assessed by an optical contact angle measurement system (OCA-20; Data Physics GmbH, Filderstadt, Germany). The water contact angle (CA) was measured at room temperature with the de-ionized water. The CA
of four different locations on the surface of each membrane sample was measured and the average values were reported as the CA value.

sections.heading: 2.5. Gas permeation measurement
sections.text:
The permeation properties of the prepared membranes were analyzed by a gas permeation set-up that is able to control the operating temperature and pressure (Fig. 2). A stainless pre-calibration cross flow flat sheet permeation cell with an effective area of 12.5 cm 2 , constant volume and variable pressure was used for the gas permeation experiments. Pure gas permeation was tested in the sequence of N2, O2 and CO2. The permeation measurements were performed at different temperatures (25, 35 and 45°C) and pressures (3, 5 and 7 bars). sections.heading: 3.1. Characterization of the synthesized zeolite nanoparticles
sections.text:
The results of characterization tests on the synthesized zeolite are presented in Fig. 3. The XRD pattern of the prepared zeolite is given in Fig. 3a. The XRD pattern was in good agreement with the results from the XRD powder pattern for the FAU zeolite [24-26] and clearly indicated that the synthesized crystal is pure FAU zeolite. Also, the crystal size of zeolite that was calculated using Scherrer’s equation from the width of peak with 2θ of 6° was found to be 15 nm [22, 24]. In addition, the XRD results show that the nano NaX zeolite sample has 93% crystalline. The FESEM image of the synthesized zeolite NaX is shown in Fig. 3b which obviously indicates that the zeolite particles were morphologically similar. Furthermore, the Si/Al ratio of 1.25 was

The specific surface area was also measured with nitrogen adsorption and BET method. The specific surface area of 536 m 2 /g was observed for the synthesized zeolite nanoparticles. In addition, the DLS analysis was applied to determine the particle size distribution of zeolite NaX nanoparticles and the results are represented in Fig. 3c. As shown in this figure, the particle size of nano-zeolite NaX was within a range of 50-200 nm and the average particle size was smaller than 100 nm. Also, the results of DLS analysis are in good agreement with the results of XRD and SEM analyses. The SEM image of the commercial zeolite NaX is shown in Fig. 3d and it can be seen that the particles have wide particle size distribution of 1-3 µm.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. ATR-FTIR
sections.text:
The ATR-FTIR spectra of the Pebax-1657 membrane and mixed matrix membrane containing 2%wt. zeolite (M4 membrane sample) are shown in Fig. 4. In the ATR-FTIR spectra of the neat membrane, the absorption bands at 1104 and 830 cm -1 are attributed to the ether function group in the PEO block [24, 27] of the Pebax molecules and the characteristic peaks at wave numbers of 1630-1539 cm -1 and 3293-3061 cm -1 are related to the amide bonds and N-H group in the PA6 block [27, 28], respectively. As indicated in Fig. 4b, some additional absorbance peaks appeared in the ATR-FTIR spectra of the M4 membrane which can be ascribed to the presence of zeolite NaX in the MMM. The peaks at 800-1200 cm -1 are due to the zeolite NaX interaction bands in the MMM [24, 29]. The nano-NaX indicates a distinct new bond at 950 cm -1 due to the Si-O group [19, 29]. Also, the changes in the peaks at wave numbers of 1104 and 830 cm -1 are related to the interaction of zeolite NaX with the C-O-C group of the PEO block [10, 15]. The
(d) ( )
absorbance peak at 3500 cm -1 is attributed to the hydrogen bonding which may be formed between zeolite and polymer [12, 30].
Fig. 4: The ATR-FTIR spectra of the prepared membranes: M1 (a) and M4 (b).

sections.heading: 3.2.2. SEM
sections.text:
The SEM analysis was employed to investigate the top surface and cross-sectional morphology of the neat and MMMs at different amounts of filler loading to reveal dispersion of zeolite particles into the Pebax-1657 matrix and interfacial adhesion of the polymer and inorganic fillers. The SEM images from the surface and cross-section of the neat Pebax membrane and zeolite filled MMMs are represented in Figs. 5 and 6, respectively. Fig. 5 displays that the surface of the neat membrane is clean and homogeneous, while some bright spots can be observed on the surface of the MMMs containing zeolite NaX particles. the zeolite on the surface of MMMs. The amount of zeolite on the membrane surface increased with an enhancement in the zeolite content of the MMMs, as shown in Fig. 5. It is also found that at lower zeolite loading, the fillers are well distributed in the polymeric matrix, however, at a higher loading (4 %wt.), the zeolite nanoparticles were agglomerated. Furthermore, the cross-sectional SEM images of the membranes (Fig. 6) indicate that a dense top layer with thickness of about 15 μm was formed on a PES ultra-porous substrate without any crack or defect and the zeolite NaX nanoparticles were presented in the selective top layer of the MMMs. The PES support layer is an asymmetric ultrafiltration membrane with porosity, average pore size and pure water flux of 75%, 12 nm and 17.7 kg/m 2 .h, respectively [23]. Also, the crosssectional SEM image of the MMM containing 2%wt. zeolite (M4 membrane sample) indicates that the zeolite nanoparticles were suitably distributed in the Pebax-1657 matrix without any aggregation and void in the zeolite/polymer interface. The polymer adhered well to zeolite particles due to the rubbery nature of the continuous phase (polymer) and presence of the soft segments in the polymer. The comparison of SEM images of the MMMs containing 2%wt. zeolite in different particle size (M4 and M6 membrane samples) obviously illustrated that the particle size of zeolite NaX has a significant effect on the morphology and structure of the prepared membranes. It can be seen in Figs. 5g, 5h, 6c and 6d, the zeolite nanoparticles were well dispersed in the Pebax matrix, whereas a island-like structure were observed as micro-sized particle were employed (Figs. 5k, 5i, 6g and 6h).

sections.heading: 3.2.3. AFM
sections.text:
The AFM analysis was used to evaluate the changes in the surface morphology and roughness of the prepared membranes. The AFM topography images of the pure Pebax-1657and MMMs are presented in Fig. 7. The values of average roughness and root mean square of the Z data of different membranes are given in Table 2. The results of AFM analysis reveal that the surface roughness of the MMMs is higher than the neat Pebax-1657 membrane. For the MMMs, the roughness increases with an enhancement in the zeolite loading of the membranes. This means that as the filler content of the Pebax layer varied from 0 to 4%wt., the amount of zeolite particles on the membrane surface enhances and results in a rougher membrane surface. Also, the generation of the concave-convex and wrinkled surface of MMMs is because of the variation in polymer chain that interacted with the nanoparticle. The AFM data confirms variations in the surface roughness of the membrane samples, which were observed in the SEM images.

sections.heading: 3.2.4. Contact angle
sections.text:
In order to characterize the changes in the membrane hydrophilicity, the contact angle tests for the neat Pebax-1657 membrane and Pebax-1657/NaX MMMs were used. Table 3 lists the results of the water contact angle measurements. As can be observed, the contact angle of the prepared membranes decreases from 65° to 47°, as the zeolite content of the Pebax layer varied from 0 to 4%wt. This implied that the membranes hydrophilicity increases with loading of zeolite NaX that is known as a high hydrophilic filler [24].

sections.heading: 3.2.5. DSC
sections.text:
The DSC analysis was utilized to recognize the interaction between the Pebax-1657 and nanozeolite NaX by determination of the glass transient temperature. Fig. 8 indicates the DSC curves for the neat pebax-1657 membrane and MMMs. It can be seen that by adding nano-zeolite into the polymer matrix, the Tg increases from -57.83°C for the pure Pebax-1657 to -50.42 °C for the MMM containing 4%wt. nano-zeolite NaX. This thermal behavior for the MMM is due to rigidification of the polymer chains around the nanoparticles and increasing interfacial
interaction. The increase in Tg by the addition of zeolite as filler into the polymeric matrixes has been previously reported by other researchers [12, 13, 17, 31, 32].
Fig. 8: The DSC curves of the M1 (a), M3 (b), M4 (c) and M5 (d) membrane samples.

sections.heading: 3.3. Gas permeation results
sections.text:
The gas separation performance of the neat Pebax-1657 and Pebax-1657/zeolite NaX MMMs was assessed by the permeation test of O2, N2 and CO2. Also, the effects of nano-zeolite NaX loading, zeolite NaX particle size, feed pressure and operating temperature on the membrane permeability and ideal selectivity were investigated. In order to ensure the reproducibility of the results, the permeability of each gas through each membrane was measured three times and the average values were reported. The observed relative error was ca. ±2-10%.

The gas separation performance of the prepared membranes as a function of the zeolite content at 25°C and 3 bar is indicated in Fig. 9. As can be seen, the permeability of the gases through all of the membranes increases in the order of CO2>O2>N2. This gas transport behavior can be explained according to the solution-diffusion mechanism. Based on the solution–diffusion model, both gas sorption and diffusion in the membrane determine the permeability of penetrant gases through the membrane. Moreover, the gas properties like condensability and size affect the sorption and diffusion in the membrane [33]. Generally, the gas condensability that can be expressed in terms of gas critical temperature affects the gas sorption in the membrane, while the size of the permeating molecule has an influence on the gas diffusion in the membrane. The more condensable gases have higher gas sorption and the smaller permeating gas has higher diffusion coefficient through the membrane. The critical temperature and kinetic diameter of CO2, O2 and N2 is 304.2, 154.6 and 126.2 K and 3.3, 3.46 and 3.64 Å, respectively [33]. CO2 is more condensable, thus it is more soluble in Pebax-1657 than other gases and the kinetic diameter of CO2 is also smaller than O2 and N2, leading to the greater diffusivity compared to other gases. Therefore, the higher sorption and diffusion of CO2 in the active layer of the membranes leads to higher CO2 permeability through all of the prepared membranes. Fig. 9 also indicates the influence of zeolite NaX content on the gas separation properties of the Pebax-1657 membrane. It can be seen that incorporation of nano-zeolite NaX has a significant effect on the gas separation properties of the membranes. The permeability of all the gases decreases and the ideal selectivity of CO2/N2 and O2/N2 increased, after zeolite NaX loading into the Pebax. According to the solution-diffusion mechanism, the gas permeation in the polymeric membrane depends on both the gas sorption and diffusion phenomena. Incorporation of inorganic fillers into the polymer matrix may be affected both sorption and diffusion steps. The
non-ideal interface in MMMs like polymer chain rigidification and pore blockage can impede the gas diffusion in the membrane and leads to lower gas permeability. On the other hand, presence of inorganic filler on the surface of the membrane significantly affects the gas sorption into the membrane, because the thermodynamic interactions between the permeating components and the membrane directly determine the level of sorption. Furthermore, this behavior can be attributed to the interactions between the nano-zeolite and polymer chains of the Pebax, i.e. rigidification of polymeric chains and partial pore blockage of filler particles. Incorporation of zeolite nanoparticles into the Pebax matrix limits the movement of the polymer chains through the formation of hydrogen bonding between the zeolite NaX and Pebax-1657 as confirmed by the ATR-FTIR results (Fig. 4b). Also, the DSC analysis confirmed the rigidification of polymeric chains by loading nano-zeolite, as observed the mixed matrix membrane had higher Tg than the neat one (Fig. 8). Furthermore, the SEM analysis (Fig. 6d) revealed that zeolite NaX nanoparticles were entirely surrounded by the Pebax-1657 chain due to the rubbery nature of polymer matrix, which may obstruct a part of zeolite pores because of attaching to the zeolite NaX surfaces. The chain rigidification affects a very thin layer of the polymer around the zeolite nanoparticles which results in the partial reduction in the gas permeability and the major decrease in the permeability is attributed to the pore blockage and decrease in the membrane free volume [3, 34]. In MMMs, the pore blockage may increment the selectivity when the original pore size of the filler is greater than the permeating gas diameter [3]. Whereas the pore size of zeolite NaX (7.4 Å) is greater than the kinetic diameter of the permeating gas, i.e. CO2 (3.3Å), O2 (3.46Å) and N2 (3.64Å), so the pore obstruction is one of the factors that can cause the increase of selectivity. Therefore, the lower CO2 permeability of the mixed matrix membranes in comparison to the neat Pebax membrane can be related to increase in the chain rigidification and
decrease in the membrane free volume as well as to the pore blockage, and the increase in CO2 permeability by increasing of the zeolite NaX content from 0.5 to 2 %wt., can be attributed to the enhancement in the gas sorption into membrane. As observed in the SEM images from the surface of the prepared membranes (Fig. 5), the amount of zeolite on the membrane surface increases with an enhancement in the zeolite content of the MMMs, thus the interaction between the CO2 molecules and membrane enhances and CO2 sorption level and leads to higher gas permeability. Based on these explanations, it can be concluded that the pore blockage of filler particles is the main reason for the decrease of the gas permeability and improvement of selectivity and the polymer chain rigidification has a little effect on the gas transport through the mixed matrix membranes. As shown in Fig. 9b, the ideal selectivity of CO2/N2 and O2/N2 enhances as the zeolite NaX content of the MMMs increases from 0.5 to 2 %wt., and a further increase in the zeolite content leads to a remarkable decrease in the CO2/N2 selectivity. This trend can be ascribed to the influence of the zeolite content on the gas permeabilities. As indicated in Fig. 9a, when the zeolite NaX content varies from 0.5 to 2 %wt., the permeability of CO2 enhances due to the chemical affinity of CO2 with zeolite NaX and high sorption capacity of zeolite NaX for polar gases. However, the N2 permeability demonstrates an opposite trend. Based on the above explanations, the diffusion of gaseous molecules with larger size through the mixed matrix membrane becomes harder with an increase in the filler loading, thus the N2 permeability decreases. Therefore, the CO2/N2 selectivity that is related to the ratio of gas permeabilities enhances with increasing zeolite loading. At higher zeolite content (4%wt.) the ideal selectivity of CO2/N2 decreases due to the aggregation of zeolite NaX nanoparticles as confirmed by the SEM analysis (Fig. 6f). This investigation is compatible with other literature data that reveal an increase of selectivity with a corresponding decrease in permeability [11, 31, 35].
For comparison, the CO2 permeability and CO2/N2 selectivity of various neat Pebax-1657 membranes are given in Table 4. It can be seen that the CO2 permeability for the neat Pebax membrane is very different from the ones reported in the literature. These discrepancies can be attributed to different fabrication conditions for the membrane preparation and also to different operating conditions for the gas permeation test. Several factors have effect on the CO2 permeability in the polymeric membrane including membrane thickness, polymer concentration, operating condition and so forth. For example, in comparison to the neat Pebax membrane prepared by Murali et al. [10], the differences between operating pressure, polymer concentration in the casting solution and solvent are the main factors which lead to the variation of CO2 permeability, although the membrane thickness in Murali et al. [10] is approximately equal to the thickness of Pebax membrane in the present work. Generally, higher polymer concentration results in a denser membrane which is followed by lower gas permeability. As presented in Table 4, the membrane thickness and polymer concentration in the casting solution for the membrane prepared by Yu et al. [13] are different with our work and cause the discrepancies in the CO2 permeability.

sections.heading: 3.3.2. Effect of zeolite particle size
sections.text: The influence of zeolite particle size at on the separation performance of the mixed matrix membrane containing 2 %wt. zeolite is presented in Table 5. It can be seen that the CO2/N2 and O2/N2 selectivities of the mixed matrix membranes significantly decreased by using the microsized zeolite. This behavior can be related to the unique phase morphology and high surface area of the nanostructure material as observed in the SEM images (Figs. 5g, 5h, 5k, 5i and Figs. 6c, 6d, 6g, 6h). As the particle size decreased from R1 to R2, the total external area and the number of the zeolite particles increased by factor of R1/R2 and (R1/R2) 3 , respectively [36]. Thus, smaller zeolite particles would provide more polymer/particle interfacial area and increase the polymer/zeolite interface contact [1, 5]. In fact, when smaller zeolite particles were employed, the area and number of polymer/zeolite interfacial in which gas molecules have to cross enhanced, hence the severity of the mass transfer resistance for gaseous molecules with larger size (i.e. N2 and O2) through the mixed matrix membrane increased and the permeability decreased. On the other hand, in sight of molecular interaction, the attractive forces among MMMs containing nano zeolite NaX, as filler, with high polar gas molecules (i.e. CO2) increased that led to enhancing the chemical affinity and permeability. Therefore, the nanostructure MMMs have higher CO2 permeability and CO2/N2 and O2/N2 selectivities in comparison to the microstructure MMM.

sections.heading: 3.3.3. Effect of feed pressure
sections.text:
The influence of feed pressure on the gas permeation properties of the mixed matrix membrane containing 2%wt. zeolite NaX is indicated in Fig. 10. It can be seen that the permeability of CO2 increases but the permeability of N2 and O2 partly reduces as the feed pressure varies from 3 to 7 bar. The observed trend for CO2 permeability is a typical behavior for the rubbery polymers that reported in the literature [8, 31, 33, 37, 38]. Generally, for condensable gases like CO2, the operating pressure has a significant influence on the gas sorption into the rubbery membranes and the sorption increases with an enhancement in pressure. On the other hand, higher CO2 sorption into the MMMs at higher pressure affects the diffusion phenomenon through the membrane via increasing the free volume. The increase in the gas sorption leads to higher mobility of the polymer chains and produces more free volume in the membrane matrix, and consequently, the gas diffusion through the membrane enhances. Therefore, the increase in the gas sorption and diffusion results in higher CO2 permeability by increasing the feed pressure. The detected trend for N2 and O2 permeabilities is consistent with other literature [14, 15, 31]. For example, Zhao et al. [14] reported that the N2 and CO2 permeabilities through the Pebax/SAPO-34 mixed matrix membrane decreased and increased, respectively, as the pressure enhanced. Ahmad and Hagg [30] also observed that the N2 and O2 permeabilities through the polyvinyl acetate/zeolite 4A mixed matrix membrane decreased as the feed pressure increased from 2 to 8 bar. The decrease in N2 and O2 permeabilities with an increase in the feed pressure can be attributed to: i) compaction of membrane at higher pressure which leads to the lower free volume in the membrane matrix, ii) the larger kinetic diameter of N2 and O2 that make harder their diffusion through the membrane, and iii) the sorption of the non-polar and non-interacting
gas molecules into the membrane remains constant or decreases with an enhancement in feed pressure [32, 37]. N2 and O2 do not plasticize the polymer matrix and, therefore, the competing effect dominates. The increase in feed pressure tends to slightly reduce polymer free volume and, in turn, reduce N2 and O2 permeabilities. Moreover, Fig. 10b reveals the effect of pressure on ideal selectivity. As can be seen, with increasing pressure from 3 to 7 bar, the ideal selectivity of CO2/N2strongly increased, however selectivity for O2/N2 slightly decreased. This behavior can be described based on the influence of feed pressure on the permeability of CO2, O2 and N2 through the Pebax/zeolite NaX mixed matrix membrane.

sections.heading: 3.3.4. Effect of operating temperature
sections.text:
In order to study the influence of the operating temperature on the gas separation performance of the fabricated membranes, the temperature was changed from 25°C to 45°C. Fig. 11 shows the influence of operating temperature on the gas permeation properties of the mixed matrix membrane containing 2%wt. zeolite NaX. As indicated in Fig. 11a, the permeability of all gases increases with the temperature evolution. This can be due to the fact that during the gas permeation in polymeric membranes, permeating gas molecules diffuse through the free volumes in the membrane. The free volumes are randomly formed by thermal motions of the polymer chains in the amorphous regions. The frequency and amplitude of the polymer jumping chains
(b)
enhance with increasing temperature and lead to more free volume in the membrane. Thus, the gas diffusion through the membrane enhances at higher temperatures resulting in higher gas permeability. Furthermore, the effect of temperature on the gas transport properties like the gas solubility, diffusivity and permeability can be expressed by the Arrhenius–van’t Hoff relation [39]:

where S, D and P are the gas solubility, diffusion and permeability coefficients, respectively, So, Do and Po are the pre-exponential factors, T is the absolute temperature and R is the gas constant. Ep and Ed are the activation energy for the permeation and diffusion, respectively and ∆Hs is the heat of solution. Ed is always positive; hence according to Eq. (4), the gas diffusion coefficient generally increases with increasing the temperature, as previously discussed. Ed is a strong function of the size of the permeating molecules, which means it is greater for the gases with larger kinetic diameter and thus for the larger gases, the diffusion is relatively more dependent on the temperature. The activation energy of the permeation signifies the total energy required for penetrants to permeate through the membrane. The amount of EP may be positive or negative based on the relative magnitude of ΔHs and Ed. For positive Ep, the gas permeability increases with temperature, while
for negative values of Ep the amount of permeability decreases with an increase in the temperature. The values of Ep for CO2, O2 and N2 at various feed pressure were calculated by fitting a linear relation on the logarithmic gas permeability curves versus the reciprocal absolute temperature. The calculated activation energy of the permeation for the mixed matrix membranes containing 2%wt. zeolite is given in Table 6. As indicated in this table, the activation energy of permeation for all gases is positive, so an enhancement in the operating temperature leads to the higher gas permeability. Also, CO2 and N2 have the lowest and highest activation energy of permeation, respectively. This implies that the permeation of N2through the membrane is higher temperature dependent thanCO2 and O2.When the activation energy of permeation is high, the gas permeation through the membrane will be more sensitive to temperature; therefore, N2 is more sensitive to temperature changes. The results observed here are similar to the reported data in the literatures by other researchers [8, 14, 17, 31]. In addition, Fig. 11b indicates the reduction of gas selectivity with an increase in temperature. As explained above, the permeability of all gases increases with increasing the operating temperature, but this change is much more for N2 due to the higher activation energy of permeation. On the other hand, an increase in temperature enhances N2 permeability more significantly than that of CO2 and O2 resulting in a decrease in the CO2/N2 and O2/N2 selectivity.

sections.heading: 3.3.5. Comparison with other research
sections.text:
For comparison purposes, the gas separation performance of the Pebax based MMMs reported by other research groups are listed in Table 7. It is observed that the CO2/N2 and O2/N2selectivities of the MMM containing 2%wt. zeolite NaX prepared in this work are higher than those of most Pebax based MMMs reported in the literature as well as the nano zeolite NaX filled Pebax membrane has a reasonable gas permeability for CO2, N2 and O2. For instance, the Pebax/zeolite NaX mixed matrix membrane with loading of 2%wt. nano-zeolite has the gas permeability of 35.2, 1.2 and 0.29 Barrer for CO2, O2 and N2, respectively and selectivity of 121.5 and 4.2 for CO2/N2 and O2/N2, respectively at 7 bar and 25°C. Also, Bryan et al. [16] prepared Pebax1657/micro-sized zeolite 13X MMMs for the CO2/N2 separation and they observed the greatest CO2/N2 selectivity of 47 at the maximum zeolite loading. A comparative investigation indicates that the gas separation performance of the nano zeolite NaX filled Pebax membranes is significantly higher than the membranes prepared by Bryan et al. [16]. This trend can be attributed to the size of the filler in the mixed matrix membranes. Furthermore, the gas separation performance of the prepared MMMs was compared with Robeson’s upper bound [40] and the results are presented in Fig. 12. As can be seen in this figure, by incorporating nano-zeolite NaX in the Pebax-1657 matrix, the membrane separation performance is close to Robeson’s upper bound. For CO2/N2 separation, the MMM containing 2%wt. nano-zeolite at the operating pressure of 7 bar and temperature of 25°C overcomes the Robeson’s upper bound and has fairly good gas separation performance in comparison to the similar Pebax mixed matrix membranes.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Mixed matrix membranes with different loading of nano-zeolite NaX in Pebax-1657 were successfully fabricated and their gas separation performance at various feed pressures and operating temperatures was studied. The prepared membranes were characterized by the ATRFTIR, SEM, AFM, DSC and contact angle analyses. The SEM results revealed that at lower filler loading, the nano-zeolite NaX were uniformly dispersed in the polymer matrix without any aggregation and defects, while the zeolite nanoparticles were agglomerated at zeolite content of 4%wt. The ATR-FTIR analysis also showed that incorporation of nano-NaX into Pebax-1657 led to the absorbance peaks at wave numbers of 800-1200 cm -1 indicating the interaction between inorganic fillers and polymer matrix. Based on the DSC analysis, the MMM had higher Tg than the neat Pebax-1657 membrane which indicated the rigidification of polymer chains around the zeolite nanoparticles. The gas permeation results showed that incorporation of nano-zeolite NaX into the Pebax matrix had a significant influence on the gas separation performance of the Pebax1657 as the ideal selectivity of CO2/N2 and O2/N2 increased and the permeability of all the gases decreased after the addition of zeolite NaX. Also, the zeolite particle size had significant effect on the gas separation performance of MMMs as the membrane containing nano-sized zeolite had superior gas separation performance in comparison with the micro-sized zeolite loaded mixed matrix membrane. It is found that the gas separation performance of the prepared membranes remarkably depends on the properties of permeating gas molecules and the operating pressure and temperature. As the operating temperature increased from 25 to 45°C, the permeability of all gases enhanced, but the gas selectivities decreased. It was observed that the permeability of CO2 and CO2/N2 selectivity increased as the feed pressure varies from 3 to 7 bar, while the permeability of N2 and O2 partly reduced. In the case of CO2/N2 separation, the membrane
containing 2%wt. zeolite nanoparticles passed the Robeson’s upper bound and had the highest gas separation performance. Finally, it can be concluded that incorporation of nano-zeolite NaX is feasible to improve the gas separation performance of Pebax-1657 and it can be useful for CO2/N2 separation in power plant application and air separation.

metadata.abstractText: In this work, mixed matrix membranes (MMMs) were prepared by incorporating nano-zeolite NaX into poly (ether-block-amide) (Pebax-1657) as an active layer on the polyethersulfone (PES) membrane as a support layer. The influence of filler content, zeolite particle size and operating conditions on the gas separation performance of the prepared membranes were studied. In order to achieve this aim, the zeolite NaX nanoparticles, which were fabricated by the hydrothermal technique using microwave heating, were uniformly distributed in the polymer solution by a two-step procedure for preparation of the membrane casting solution and the mixed matrix membrane was fabricated via the phase inversion technique by solvent evaporation. The prepared membranes were characterized by the ATR-FTIR, AFM, SEM, DSC and contact angle analyses. The gas permeation results revealed that incorporation of nano-zeolite NaX into the Pebax-1657 membrane decreased the gas permeability for all tested gases, while the ideal selectivity for CO2/N2 and O2/N2 significantly enhanced. Also, the mixed matrix membranes containing nano-sized zeolite had superior gas separation performance in comparison with the micro-sized zeolite loaded membrane.
